hog they say
"H.H." for "His Highness" end then "H.M." for "His Majesty",
Therefore I always sign my first nune in full.
Left Bangkok Friday night and arrived Celeutta at 3:00 e.".
Went straight
to the Great Eastern Hotel - a neme which is appropriate only with respect to
the niddle word - and slept until 10:00 o'elock.
Calcutta is the meeting place
of our Pacifie and Atlantie services.
Left thet same night for New Delhi and
Kerschi,
Now were flying at 300 miles per hour over Saudi Arabia toward Den-
aSCuS.
Out of Demascus we climbed up high over the green irrigated plains of Syria
northward to get altitude and at 14,000 feet turned west across the snow covered
mountains of Lebanon,
Now we're out over the eastern end of the Mediterranean
which stands out in a lovely blue after the tan colored wand of Arable over which
we've been flying since daylight.
Later - we're now over the Island of Cyprus
- much larger than I had pictured it.
From here we skirt the western tip of
Geneva and on to Brussels and London.
of
course, we're flying with the sun and thus gaining several hours, but even then
it really is something to leave Delhi, India and arrive in London the same day.
The situation in the Far East is never comprehensible but now it is wholly
unpredictable.
One way to study a highly complicated problem is to examine - so
far as possible - each part one by one with the hope that an understanding of the
whole may be had by this process.
Applying that iden to the Orient the most
important factor is Chine.
Neerly every well-informed men will concede that
Chiang Kal-shek's personal government is thoroughly whipped and that the Chinese
Communists will take all of China - or at least 1l that is important - leaving
some of the inland provinces perhaps in the hands of local wer lords.
If you
point out that the spresd of Communism throughout ell southeast Asia must not
be permitted,
the well-inforned just shrug their shoulders but say the situation
is hopeless unless the
United Stetes wents to step in militarily and actually
to war with the Chinese Reds.
Such & solution is apperently out of the question
as it might and probably would lead to World War III.
Personally, I like sub-
ordinates who,
when confronted with a problem, give you & clear statenent of the
problen and follow that with a suggested course of constructive moves calculated
to solve the problen.
With that notion in mind I have thought and thought for
months to try
â€¢ to evolve a solution.
I know that on my return I will be asked
"What can
do?"
and
I hate the idea of joining all the others with & shrug
of the shoulders.
There must be some solution, but I have none to offer.
For a
while I thought
that the U.S. might send a strong man over to China with broad
powers and
financial
becking who would sit in the backroom and really run the
show in very much the same way that a bank steps into a work-out proposition with
a debtor.
I thought that perhaps & southern "beach-head" could be held from
which -
over a period
of many years - we could help some real Chinese patriots to
win back all
China
through sound measures of economy based on real money i.e.
silver rather then
pieces of paper with a hammer and sickle on them and real
prosperity rather then a five year plan.
I thought that the Commists might
settle for &
phoney
coalition government, call off the wer and leave Kwentung
Province in the hands of a completely purged Kuonintang overment; that by
throwing our complete moral and economie support back of that faction we could
win over
the materialistie Chinese to our way of life.
However, if that idea
ever had sny merit it is too late now.
The Chinese Communists,
flushed with
military successes and riding the tide of a fanatical zeal will not settle for
less than all of Chine,
except - as stated above - for a few hinterland unimpor-
tant provinces which
cannot (General Chenn ult's statements notwithstanding) be
